image1920×1080 79.4 KB

Hey, I am trying to program an offseason robot, however it is slightly overshooting in autonomous.

I think it might be a PID issue, however whenever I change the PID values for rotation controller in the path planner autobuilder it does nothing to robot’s movement. (Except D value, which makes robot ocellate)

https://github.com/frc6548/2024-Crescendo-Code

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T16:52:57.574Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":130.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Eric1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/frc6548/2024-Crescendo-Code","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - frc6548/2024-Crescendo-Code","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58672,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3412354,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T17:10:56.230Z","cooked":"

Your actual velocity is consistently higher than your commanded velocity.

Reset P=I=D to zero, and see how close you get with just your feedforward. if that is also still overshooting, adjust that back down first.

Okay that helped it looks like,
I changed
driveFeedforward from kv .13 to .09 (and left ks at 1.0)

image1920×1080 81 KB

I noticed that if I run the path again it’s not 100% accurate?

image1920×1080 85.7 KB

1.0 for your ks gain seems awfully high, trying lowering it to somewhere around 0.1.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T18:09:28.477Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":33.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Will Weiszhaar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65296,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412370,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T18:20:35.560Z","cooked":"

Considering this is path following and not starting from 0 velocity on every iteration or trying to maintain an essentially stable position, I suggest that Ks = 0 is a safe bet and removes all doubt if it’s too high.

Is th overshoot consistant in both directions?

The reason I ask is the lay of the carpet nap and colsons is a well documented issue. So there could be a reasonable mechanical explanation if this issue matches.

What type of wheels does your team use? Technical Discussion
As much as 6% error according to our tests caused by carpet nap which is too bad, we loved the Colsons but have moved on… If it wasn’t for that, Colsons are great.

Edit: upon taking the time to actually look at the graph now that I am not traveling this is not the case, but all the same leaving this linked.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-08-01T02:44:21.429Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":86,"readers_count":85,"score":37.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-type-of-wheels-does-your-team-use/362214/18","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"What type of wheels does your team use?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/8","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412403,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T21:08:32.311Z","cooked":"

Do not manually tune kV, as any manual tuning is likely to be very wrong. The kV gain should be equal to your motor’s backEMF constant plus the torque constant * viscous damping / armatrue resistnace, which is often negligable compared to the backemf constant.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T21:08:32.311Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":58672,"username":"Eric1","name":"Eric1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eric1/{size}/192260_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412406,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T21:12:11.781Z","cooked":"
Alex_Y:

Do not manually tune kV, as any manual tuning is likely to be very wrong.

Talk to me a bit more about why this is the case. It doesn’t strike me as true at face value, so I’m interested to understand where you’re coming from.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T21:12:28.578Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":20.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412407,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T21:14:26.597Z","cooked":"

Did you actually set P=I=D to zero when you ran these experiments?

If you don’t, they may be covering up a completely incorrect feedforward. It’s really hard to debug multiple things at once.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T21:14:26.597Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":19.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58672,"username":"Eric1","name":"Eric1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eric1/{size}/192260_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412408,"name":"Eric1","username":"Eric1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eric1/{size}/192260_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T21:23:53.979Z","cooked":"

yes p, i, and d were all zero

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T21:23:53.979Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Eric1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58672,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412412,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T21:49:14.910Z","cooked":"

The purpose of the kV gain is to cancel out backEMF. While it may be explained in other ways, its dynamics are equvalent to just applying the backEMF back to the motor.

Lets say you have a motor with some arbitrary load on with a backemf constant of 0.01 V-s/rad it that is voltage controlled. Lets pretend for a moment that viscous damping isn’t real.

If this motor is spinning at 1000 rad/s, 10V of backemf will be generated. Thus, to maintain its velocity at 1000 rad/s, you must apply 10V across the motor to cancel out all the backemf. If you did not cancel out the backemf, the motor would decelatate because the backemf would cause current to flow in the wrong direction. Current-controlled motors don’t require you to manually apply a kV gain because the motor controller handles the handing of the backemf.

Back to the real world, viscous damping is now a thing and can now hurt you. To maintain velocity, you must now both cancel out the backEMF and the viscous drag. Lets assume indutance isn’t real and can’t hurt you (it responds so fast that often you can ignore it). The viscous damping will exert a torque equal to the velocity times the viscous damping constant. The torque exerted by the motor is the torque constant times the current, and the current is equal to the (applied voltage - backemf voltage)/armature resistance.

Thus, you arrive back at what I’ve said earlier. Manually tuning kV means you won’t match the backemf constant, which causes your control system not match the desired RPM without having to put more work on the feedback controller than if you just analytically derived the kV gain.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T21:49:14.910Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":38.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412420,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T22:04:37.567Z","cooked":"

ok, just asking since it’s not what your screenshot says

Concur kS = 1.0 seems quite high, 0.1 is much more reasonable.

Note the paths your running involve constant acceleration - the fact that your ka is zero will mean you always have some error with feedforward only.

From there, I think I’d start trying to crank up kP. Keep doubling it until you see oscillation. Then back off a bit to get rid of the oscillation.

If that doesn’t cause your robot velocity to track desired nicely, I’d say you have something else going wrong besides just tuning.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T22:04:37.567Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58672,"username":"Eric1","name":"Eric1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eric1/{size}/192260_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412424,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T22:12:13.078Z","cooked":"
Alex_Y:

The purpose of the kV gain is to cancel out backEMF.

I do not think I agree. Here’s my source.

The purpose of kV is to decide how many volts are required to achieve a certain steady-state velocity (minus the kS effect from overcoming static friction). The things which impact this velocity include both the motor, and what it’s hooked up to - the whole system.

Indeed, for a system which has lots of velocity-dependent friction effects (esp. grease in gearboxes) - you want something to account for that in your feed-forward.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-07-31T22:15:00.642Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":37.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469367,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-feedforward.html#introduction-to-dc-motor-feedforward","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-autonomous-slightly-overshooting/469367/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3412434,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-31T22:45:39.686Z","cooked":"

In practice, I’ve never seen viscous damping be a significant factor compared to backEMF, with the backEMF contribution usually being an order of magnitude higher than the viscous damping contributions. And when it is, manual tuning isn’t an efficient way to do so as you only need to make a very slight adjustment to the kV gain to cancel out the viscous damping effects. The earlier instance of just dropping kV by a signifcant amount (also without units) shows a fundamental misunderstanding of what its doing which ends up not being as accurate as setting it to the backemf constant, maybe bumping it slightly for viscous drag and then calling it a day.

You’ve backed off enough on your argument that I think you understand my point.

Alex_Y:

The earlier instance of just dropping kV by a signifcant amount (also without units) shows a fundamental misunderstanding of what its doing

I disagree this is a valid conclusion about OP’s understanding. I’d caution implying there’s a particular level of understanding based on the changes they indicated they made.

You may also wish to investigate the docs on tuning a flywheel. If you disagree with them, keep in mind:

Trying Ks = 0 was a worthwhile experiment although my reasoning was flawed since the feedforward equation looks like a hockey stick “_/” no matter what is the starting velocity. The small value didn’t much matter.

What happened during that second acceleration period? Looks like the robot briefly hit a stiff head-wind.
